translated: Points of Controversy
The Great Fifty
Sixth Section🔽Discussion of the Truths
Are the four truths unformed?

original: Āmantā.🔽Cattāri tāṇāni cattāri leṇāni cattāri saraṇāni cattāri parāyanāni cattāri accutāni cattāri amatāni cattāri nibbānānīti?🔽Na hevaṁ vattabbe …pe…🔽cattāri nibbānānīti?🔽Āmantā.
analyzed: āmantā  cattāri tāṇāni cattāri leṇāni cattāri saraṇāni cattāri parāyanāni cattāri accutāni cattāri amatāni cattāri nibbānāni iti  na ha ivam vattabbe pe  cattāri nibbānāni iti  āmantā
translated: “Yes.”

original: Atthi catunnaṁ nibbānānaṁ uccanīcatā hīnapaṇītatā ukkaṁsāvakaṁso sīmā vā bhedo vā rāji vā antarikā vāti?🔽Na hevaṁ vattabbe …pe….🔽Dukkhasaccaṁ asaṅkhatanti?🔽Āmantā.🔽Dukkhaṁ asaṅkhatanti?🔽Na hevaṁ vattabbe …pe…🔽dukkhasaccaṁ asaṅkhatanti?🔽Āmantā.🔽Kāyikaṁ dukkhaṁ cetasikaṁ dukkhaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassaupāyāsā asaṅkhatāti?🔽Na hevaṁ vattabbe …pe…🔽samudayasaccaṁ asaṅkhatanti?🔽Āmantā.🔽Samudayo asaṅkhatoti?🔽Na hevaṁ vattabbe …pe…
analyzed: atthi catunnam nibbānānam ucca nīca tā hīna paṇīta tā ukkasa avakasaḥ sīmā vā bhedaḥ vā rāji vā antarikā vā ati 🔽na ha ivam vattabbe pe 🔽dukkha saccam asaṅkhatanti 🔽āmantā 🔽dukkham a saṅkhatanti 🔽na ha ivam vattabbe pe 🔽dukkha saccam asaṅkhatanti 🔽āmantā 🔽kāyikam dukkham cetasikam dukkham soka parideva dukkha domanassa upāyāsāḥ asaṅkhatā ati 🔽na ha ivam vattabbe pe 🔽samudaya saccam 🔽āmantā 🔽samudayaḥ 🔽na ha ivam vattabbe pe

Is the truth of the origination unconditioned?
“Yes.”

analyzed: kāma taṇhā bhava taṇhā vibhava taṇhā asaṅkhatā ati
translated: “Are craving for sense pleasures, craving for existence, and craving for non-existence unconditioned?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …
“Is the truth of the path unconditioned?”
“Yes.”
“Is the path unconditioned?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …
“Is the truth of the path unconditioned?”
“Yes.”
“Are right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration unconditioned?”
“Is it so that it is not to be said that it is a person who is the same in the eye faculty and the eye consciousness?” …
“Is suffering conditioned?”
“Yes.”
“Is the truth of suffering conditioned?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

original: kāyikaṁ dukkhaṁ cetasikaṁ dukkhaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassaupāyāsā saṅkhatāti?
analyzed: kāyikam dukkham cetasikam dukkham soka parideva dukkha domanassa upāyāsā saṅkhatā ati
translated: “Are bodily pain, mental pain, bodily pleasure, mental pleasure, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair conditioned?”
“Yes.”
“Is the truth of suffering conditioned?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …
“Is the origination conditioned?”
“Yes.”
“Is the truth of the origination conditioned?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

analyzed: kāma taṇhā bhava taṇhā vibhava taṇhā
translated: “Are craving for sense pleasures, craving for existence, and craving for non-existence conditioned?”
“Yes.”
“Is the truth of the origination conditioned?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …
Is the path formed?”
“Yes.”
“Is the truth of the path formed?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …
“Is right view … right concentration formed?”
“Yes.”
“Is the truth of the path formed?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

analyzed: nirodha saccam asaṅkhata nirodhaḥ asaṅkhata uti
translated: “Is the truth of cessation unformed? Is cessation unformed?”
“Yes.”
“Is the truth of suffering unformed? Is suffering unformed?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

analyzed: nirodha saccam asaṅkhata nirodhaḥ asaṅkhata uti
translated: “Is the truth of cessation unformed? Is cessation unformed?”
“Yes.”
“Is the truth of the origin unformed? Is the origin unformed?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

analyzed: nirodha saccam asaṅkhata nirodhaḥ asaṅkhata uti
translated: “Is the truth of cessation unformed? Is cessation unformed?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: magga saccam asaṅkhata maggaḥ asaṅkhataḥ ti
translated: “Is the truth of the path unformed? Is the path unformed?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …
“Is the truth of suffering unformed? Is suffering formed?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: nirodha saccam asaṅkhata nirodhaḥ saṅkhataḥ iti
translated: “Is the truth of cessation unformed? Is cessation formed?”
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

analyzed: samudaya saccam asaṅkhata samudayaḥ saṅkhata uti
translated: Is the truth of the origin of suffering unconditioned, while the origin of suffering is conditioned?
Yes.

analyzed: nirodha saccam asaṅkhata nirodhaḥ saṅkhataḥ iti
translated: Is the truth of the cessation of suffering unconditioned, while the cessation of suffering is conditioned?
You may not say that.

analyzed: magga saccam asaṅkhata maggo saṅkhataḥ iti
translated: Is the truth of the path unconditioned, while the path is conditioned?
Yes.

analyzed: nirodha saccam asaṅkhata nirodhaḥ saṅkhataḥ iti
translated: Is the truth of the cessation of suffering unconditioned, while the cessation of suffering is conditioned?
You may not say that.
You shouldn’t say,
‘The four truths are unconditioned.’
Yes.
But has this not been said by the Buddha?

analyzed: cattāri imāni bhikkhave tathāni avitathāni anaññathāni
translated: ‘Monks, there are these four realities that are not otherwise.
What four?🔽“This is suffering” is a reality that is not otherwise. …

original: ‘Idaṁ dukkhan’ti, bhikkhave, tathametaṁ avitathametaṁ anaññathametaṁ …pe…🔽‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti …pe…🔽‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti …pe…
analyzed: idam dukkhanti bhikkhave tatham etam avitatham etam anaññatham etam pe  ayam dukkha samudayaḥ ti pe  ayam dukkha nirodho ti pe
translated: “This is the origin of suffering” …🔽“This is the cessation of suffering” …

analyzed: ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati tatham etam avitatham etam anaññatham eta
translated: “This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering” is a reality that is not otherwise.

original: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri tathāni avitathāni anaññathānī”ti.
analyzed: imāni kho bhikkhave cattāri tathāni avitathāni anaññathāni iti
translated: These are the four realities that are not otherwise.’
Is there such a sutra?
“The invitation.”

analyzed: tena hi cattāri saccāni asaṅkhatāni iti
translated: “Well then, the four truths are unconditioned.”
The discussion of the truths is finished.
